examples: A: Yo, why you stuttering? Just spit it out.
B: My bad, I'm just nervous being around her.
A: Did you see him trying to explain that? Straight stuttering.
B: Yeah, he was definitely fumbling over his words.
A: Stop stuttering and tell me what really went down.
B: Okay, chill! I'm trying to get it out.
A: My neck is killing me, doc says it's some stenosis thing.
B: Damn, better take it easy with the gym then.
A: I can't even turn my head, this cervical stuff is no joke.
B: You need to see a chiro or something, for real.
A: My cervical disc stenosis is acting up again.
B: Sounds fancy for 'my neck is jacked up'.
A: Jessica is such a social butterfly, she knows literally everyone here.
B: Fr, she can't walk five feet without dapping someone up.
A: I'm trying to be more of a social butterfly this year.
B: Good luck, you love staying in too much though.
A: Invite Mike, he's a total social butterfly.
B: True, he'll keep the vibe alive.
A: You gotta expand your social network if you want that job.
B: I know, I need to start hitting up more events.
A: His social network is insane, he knows all the promoters.
B: Yeah, he's definitely plugged in.
A: It's not about what you know, it's about your social network.
B: Facts, connections are everything in this city.
A: That guy has zero social skills, it was so awkward.
B: I noticed, he just stared at me when I said hi.
A: You need mad social skills to work in PR.
B: for sure, you gotta know how to talk to anyone.
A: Her social skills are on point, she charmed the whole room.
B: She's got that natural rizz.
A: Companies act like they care about social responsibility just for clout.
B: Big facts, it's all just marketing usually.
A: We gotta have some social responsibility and clean this park up.
B: I'm down, let's do it for the neighborhood.
A: Social responsibility is huge for Gen Z consumers.
B: Yeah, they don't mess with brands that are shady.
A: He really doesn't care about societal norms, does he?
B: Nope, he marches to the beat of his own drum.
A: Following societal norms is so boring sometimes.
B: I feel you, sometimes you gotta break the mold.
A: Societal norms say we should settle down, but I'm just living.
B: Do you, don't worry about what people expect.

meaning: 특별히 더 신경 쓰다 / 한 발 더 뛰다
examples: A: She always goes the extra mile for her clients.
B: That's why she's the top earner in the office.
A: I'm gonna go the extra mile on this project to impress the boss.
B: Secure that promotion, I see you.
A: You didn't have to get me a gift too, you really went the extra mile.
B: You know I got you, gotta treat my friends right.
A: Let's get the ball rolling on this trip planning.
B: bet, I'll start looking at flights tonight.
A: We need to get the ball rolling if we want to finish by Friday.
B: Alright, I'm opening the doc right now.
A: Who's gonna get the ball rolling on the group chat?
B: I got it, I'll add everyone now.
A: I've never had oyster, but I'll give it a shot.
B: You might like it, just put some hot sauce on it.
A: You think I should apply? I'm not qualified.
B: Just give it a shot, you never know.
A: I'm gonna give it a shot and ask for her number.
B: Do it, bro! Shoot your shot.
A: He went out of his way to drive me to the airport.
B: That's a real friend right there.
A: Don't go out of your way if it's too much trouble.
B: Nah, it's cool, I'm headed that way anyway.
A: She really went out of her way to make me feel welcome.
B: She's sweet like that, always looking out.
A: We're trying to get this startup off the ground.
B: The beginning is always the hardest grind.
A: Once this project gets off the ground, it's gonna be huge.
B: Facts, I can see the potential.
A: It's hard to get a music career off the ground in this city.
B: Too much competition, everyone's a rapper.
A: I'm just creating peace for the sake of the family.
B: I feel that, gotta keep the drama low at Thanksgiving.
A: Let's just agree for the sake of finishing this meeting.
B: Please, I wanna go home already.
A: He quit smoking for the sake of his health.
B: Good for him, that stuff is bad news.
A: I'm crashing on my friend's couch for the time being.
B: Until you find a new spot? That's decent of him.
A: Let's stick to this plan for the time being.
B: Cool, we can switch it up later if we need to.
A: The shop is closed for the time being.
B: Dang, I really wanted a bagel.
A: Let's eat something healthy for a change.
B: You mean not pizza? Who are you?
A: It's nice to see you smiling for a change.
B: Shut up, I smile sometimes!
A: We decided to go upstate for a change.
B: Nice, get some fresh air away from the city.
A: Do you still talk to him?
B: From time to time, but not like before.
A: I like to treat myself to a spa day from time to time.
B: Self-care is important, I gotta do that more.
A: It gets really loud here from time to time.
B: Yeah, that's city living for you.

meaning: 좋을 때나 나쁠 때나 / 산전수전 다 겪으며
examples: A: They've been together through thick and thin.
B: That's real love, staying through the hard times.
A: My best friend has been with me through thick and thin.
B: Keep those people close, they're rare.
A: We gotta stick together through thick and thin.
B: Fo sho, squad for life.
A: Beyonce is a straight-up force of nature.
B: Absolutely, nobody does it like her.
A: When he gets mad, he's like a force of nature.
B: Yeah, I stay out of his way when he's heated.
A: That storm was a force of nature, so scary.
B: Mother Nature doesn't play.
A: Why did you drive to your old house?
B: Force of habit, I lived there for 10 years!
A: I checked my phone again, force of habit.
B: You're addicted, put it down.
A: Sorry I ordered regular milk, force of habit.
B: It's cool, I'll drink it.
A: He quit smoking by sheer force of will.
B: That's tough, respect to him.
A: You need strong force of will to finish a marathon.
B: For real, my legs would give out at mile 2.
A: Her force of will is scary proficient.
B: She gets what she wants, period.
A: He won the room over just by force of personality.
B: Yeah, he walks in and owns the place.
A: You can't ignore her, she has such a force of personality.
B: She definitely commands attention.
A: It takes a certain force of personality to lead like that.
B: Born leader vibes.
A: The force of impact totaled the car.
B: Damn, everyone okay though?
A: You could feel the force of impact from the bass.
B: That concert was shaking the whole block.
A: The news hit with the force of impact of a bomb.
B: Everyone was shook.
A: *Sneezes* Ugh, my allergies are acting up.
B: Bless you! The pollen count is high today.
A: I can't breathe, my allergies are acting up so bad.
B: Did you take a Zyrtec?
A: My eyes are so itchy, allergies are acting up.
B: You look high, go wash your face.

meaning: 나 좀 내버려 둬 / 잔소리 좀 그만해
examples: A: Did you finish the report yet?
B: Get off my back! I'm doing it right now.
A: I'm just asking! You don't have to snap.
B: You've asked me five times, just chill.
A: Mom just won't get off my back about getting married.
B: Parents stay stressing us out.

primary: Lets pick up where we left off
meaning: 아까 하던 얘기 계속하자 / 여기서부터 다시 시작하자
examples: A: Sorry I had to take that call. Where were we?
B: Let's pick up where we left off, discussing the budget.
A: We ran out of time yesterday, let's pick up where we left off.
B: Cool, pull up the slide deck.
A: I wanna pick up where we left off on our date.
B: Smooth... drinks at 8?

primary: I just bumped my elbow on the doorframe
examples: A: Oww! I just bumped my elbow on the doorframe.
B: That funny bone pain is the worst!
A: You okay? You winced hard.
B: Yeah, just bumped my elbow on the doorframe. My arm is tingling.
A: Watch out for that doorframe.
B: Too late, just bumped my elbow. RIP my arm.
A: You didn't give up even when it got hard. You have grit.
B: Momma raised a fighter.
A: I respect how you handled that loss. You have grit.
B: Fall down seven times, stand up eight.
A: To make it in NYC, you gotta have grit.
B: Facts, this city will chew you up otherwise.
A: You really talked back to the boss? You have guts.
B: Someone had to say it.
A: I can't believe you jumped off that cliff. You have guts.
B: It was a rush!
A: Asking for a raise on your first day? You have guts.
B: Know your worth, add tax.
A: You want to try that new fusion spot?
B: Always down, I'm a foodie.
A: She posts food pics all day.
B: Yeah, she claims 'I'm a foodie' in her bio.
A: Since I'm a foodie, NYC is paradise.
B: Too many options, not enough stomach space.

meaning: 이제 더 이상은 못 참아 / 이게 한계야
examples: A: He flaked on plans again.
B: That's the last straw, block his number.
A: If my boss yells one more time, it's the last straw.
B: Don't quit without a backup plan though.
A: The wifi cut out during the game. It's the last straw.
B: Time to switch providers.
A: I'm bored. Wanna catch a movie later?
B: Sure, what's playing?
A: Work was stress. Wanna catch a movie later to unwind?
B: I'm down, let's get popcorn too.
A: Wanna catch a movie later?
B: Nah, let's just Netflix and chill.
A: You think it's gonna rain?
B: With those clouds? It seems a bit likely.
A: Is he gonna get the promotion?
B: It seems a bit likely, the boss loves him.
A: She might flake.
B: Knowing her? It seems a bit likely.

meaning: 좀 오바한 것 같더라 / 과장된 것 같아
examples: A: Did you believe his story?
B: Nah, it seemed a bit exaggerated.
A: Her reaction was wild.
B: Yeah, it seemed a bit exaggerated for just a spilled drink.
A: The news report made it sound like a war zone.
B: Clickbait, bro. It seemed a bit exaggerated.
A: Is he coming or not?
B: I don't know, he's being so wishy washy.
A: Don't be wishy washy, pick a restaurant!
B: Everything sounds good though!
A: I hate dealing with wishy washy clients.
B: Same, just sign the contract already.

meaning: 일단 비밀로 해 / 입 닫고 있어
examples: A: I'm planning a surprise party for her.
B: details? And keep a lid on it.
A: Did you hear about the merger?
B: Yeah, but keep a lid on it until it's official.
A: I don't want everyone knowing my business.
B: Don't worry, I'll keep a lid on it.

primary: What do you take me for?
meaning: 사람을 아주 물로 보네? / 내가 호구로 보여?
similar: Am I a joke to you?
examples: A: I'll pay you back next year.
B: What do you take me for? An idiot?
A: You think I did this for money?
B: What do you take me for? I did it for us.
A: Just sign it without reading.
B: What do you take me for? I'm reading every word.

primary: I'm not the type to regret things
meaning: 나 원래 후회 잘 안 해 / 뒤끝 없는 스타일이야
examples: A: Do you wish you hadn't moved here?
B: Nah, I'm not the type to regret things.
A: That tattoo is wild.
B: Whatever, I'm not the type to regret things.
A: You burnt a bridge there.
B: It is what it is. I'm not the type to regret things.

primary: I am at a loss for words
meaning: 뭐라 할 말이 없네 / 어이가 없네
examples: A: Did you see that outfit?
B: I am at a loss for words. It was... interesting.
A: The view from here is insane.
B: Wow, I am at a loss for words. So beautiful.
A: He actually said that?
B: Yes, I am at a loss for words. The audacity.

primary: In one ear, out the other
meaning: 한 귀로 듣고 한 귀로 흘려 / 귓등으로도 안 들어
examples: A: Did you tell him to take out the trash?
B: Yeah, but it went in one ear, out the other.
A: She never listens to advice.
B: Literally, in one ear, out the other.
A: I feel like I'm talking to a wall.
B: Same, everything goes in one ear, out the other with him.
A: You're late again.
B: Cut me some slack, the train was delayed!
A: This isn't your best work.
B: I'm running on two hours of sleep, cut me some slack.
A: Why is your room messy?
B: Cut me some slack, I've been working all week.

meaning: 무슨 일 있어? / 뭐 찜찜한 거 있어?
examples: A: You've been quiet all night. Is something bothering you?
B: just tired, honestly.
A: Is something bothering you? You keep checking your phone.
B: Waiting for a text, that's all.
A: You seem annoyed. Is something bothering you?
B: Yeah, actually, we need to talk.

primary: It's nothing. Don't worry about it.
examples: A: What did you say?
B: It's nothing. Don't worry about it.
A: Are you mad?
B: Nah, it's nothing. Don't worry about it.
A: Sorry I broke your pen.
B: It's nothing. Don't worry about it, I have ten more.

meaning: 고통받느니 죽는 게 낫지 / 힘들게 사느니 죽고 말지
examples: A: We have to walk 20 blocks in the rain.
B: I'd rather die than suffer through that. Uber?
A: You want to watch that 4-hour documentary?
B: I'd rather die than suffer that boredom.
A: Drama with the ex again?
B: Ugh, I'd rather die than suffer his nonsense.
A: How was the interview?
B: It was so nerve racking, I was shaking.

B: Tell me about it, my heart is pounding.

B: Just be yourself, you got this.

B: Trying to butter him up so I can borrow the car.

B: Yeah, she wants that promotion bad.

B: Worth a shot though, right?
A: Look at him bringing coffee for everyone.
B: Total brown nose move.
A: Nobody likes a brown nose.
B: But the boss loves him, so who's winning?
A: Stop being a brown nose and have an opinion.
B: I'm just being a team player!
A: You'll never guess who I bumped into today.
B: Who? Your ex?
A: I bumped into Sarah at the bodega.
B: No way, how is she doing?

B: Pretend you didn't see them. Valid strategy.
A: Sorry, I think I bumped against your table.
B: It's cool, no water spilled.
A: The subway was so crowded, I bumped against like ten people.
B: Rush hour vibes, gotta love it.
A: I bumped against the wall in the dark.
B: Ouch, you okay?

primary: I hot.my toe bumped on yhe doorframe
examples: A: Why are you hopping around?
B: I bumped my toe on the doorframe! It hurts so bad!
A: Ouch, did you break it?
B: Feels like it! Why do I keep doing this?
A: Watch where you're walking.
B: I swear the doorframe moved.

primary: I bumped my toes on the doorframe
examples: A: *Screams silently*
B: What happened? You look in pain.
A: I bumped my toes on the doorframe.
B: The worst pain known to man. RIP.
A: I need steel-toed boots in this house.
B: Clumsy much?

B: Yeah, he's such a pushover.
A: Don't be a pushover, tell them no.
B: It's hard, I hate conflict.

B: Kids can be ruthless.

B: I think he has a girlfriend.
A: Are you spoken for, or can I buy you a drink?
B: I'm spoken for, but thanks for the offer.
A: Everyone at this party is spoken for.
B: Single life is rough out here.

meaning: 걔 사진 찍는 거 싫어해 / 카메라 공포증 있어
examples: A: Let's take a selfie!
B: Don't ask Mike, he is pretty camera shy.
A: Why are there no photos of him online?
B: He is pretty camera shy, likes his privacy.
A: He hid his face again.
B: Yeah, he is pretty camera shy.

primary: He was three years above me
examples: A: You know Dave?
B: Yeah, he was three years above me in high school.
A: Did you guys hang out?
B: Not really, since he was three years above me.
A: He seems older.
B: He is, he was three years above me in college.

primary: She was three years below me
examples: A: Who's that girl?
B: Emily. She was three years below me in school.
A: So she's younger?
B: Yeah, she was three years below me.
A: I barely knew anyone who was three years below me.
B: Different crowds, makes sense.
A: How long will it take?
B: An hour, give or take.
A: How much was the bill?
B: Like 50 bucks, give or take.
A: He's like 6 feet tall, give or take.
B: Probably 5'11" on a good day.
A: I guessed she was 25.
B: You are way off, she's 40.
A: Is the answer 100?
B: Way off. Try 1000.
A: His estimate for the project was way off.
B: Yeah, we're over budget now.
A: I gotta use the bathroom. Save my seat.
B: Got you, be quick though.
A: Can you save my seat while I grab a drink?
B: Sure, but if Beyonce walks in, she gets it.
A: Did you save my seat?
B: I tried, but some guy just sat down.

meaning: 방사 유정란 / 풀어 키운 닭이 낳은 알
examples: A: Why are these eggs 8 dollars?
B: They're pasture raised eggs, top tier.
A: I only buy pasture raised eggs now.
B: Boujee! But do they taste better?
A: Pasture raised eggs have orange yolks, it's wild.
B: Nutrient density, fam.

meaning: 딱 촉이 와 / 왠지 그럴 것 같아
examples: A: You think he's lying?
B: Yeah, I have a gut feeling.
A: Why did you turn left?
B: I have a gut feeling this is a shortcut.
A: Don't trust that deal.
B: Same, I have a gut feeling it's a scam.
A: Why is she asking so many questions?
B: She's such a busybody, ignore her.
A: Don't be a busybody, let them live.
B: I'm just curious!
A: Our neighbor is a total busybody.
B: Always watching from the window, right?

primary: Don't get me started on her boyfriend
meaning: 걔 남친 얘기는 꺼내지도 마 / 말도 마라
examples: A: Is she still with that guy?
B: Don't get me started on her boyfriend, he's the worst.
A: I heard they fought.
B: Don't get me started on her boyfriend, drama 24/7.
A: Is he nice?
B: Girl, don't get me started on her boyfriend.
A: It's raining on our beach day.
B: It can't be helped, let's go to a museum.
A: The flight is delayed.
B: It can't be helped, grab a beer?
A: I wish I could fix it.
B: It can't be helped, don't stress.
A: Why did you take that job?
B: Out of necessity, bills were piling up.
A: She learned to cook out of necessity.
B: Yeah, takeout gets expensive.
A: We moved here out of necessity.
B: Gotta go where the work is.

meaning: 다른 방법이 없어 / 선택의 여지가 없어
examples: A: You really sold your car?
B: I had no other choice, needed the cash.
A: Why did you agree?
B: No other choice, they pressured me.
A: We have no other choice but to walk.
B: Ugh, my feet already hurt.

meaning: 네가 말을 꺼내서 하는 얘긴데 / 말이 나온 김에
examples: A: This room is messy.
B: Since you bring it up, you never clean either.
A: We need to save money.
B: Since you bring it up, stop buying coffee.
A: He seems distracted.
B: Since you bring it up, I noticed that too.
A: I'm going to the store.
B: While at it, grab some milk?
A: I'm fixing the sink.
B: While at it, can you check the toilet too?
A: Deleting old emails.
B: While at it, clear your trash folder.

meaning: 그냥 대충 하는 거야 / 영혼 없이 하는 중이야
examples: A: You like your job?
B: Nah, I'm just going through the motions.
A: You seem checked out.
B: Yeah, I'm just going through the motions lately.
A: Is he serious about her?
B: Doesn't look like it, he's just going through the motions.
A: You gonna jump?
B: Here goes nothing! *Jumps*
A: Time to ask for that raise.
B: Here goes nothing. Fingers crossed.
A: Trying this spicy noodle challenge.
B: Here goes nothing. RIP my stomach.

primary: I'm not the type to regret things easily
meaning: 나 원래 쉽게 후회 안 해
examples: A: Do you regret dating him?
B: Nah, I'm not the type to regret things easily.
A: You spent a lot on that bag.
B: Worth it. I'm not the type to regret things easily.
A: That was a risky move.
B: I live for it. I'm not the type to regret things easily.
A: Wanna get dinner?
B: Let's hit that conveyor belt sushi spot.
A: Conveyor belt sushi is fun but dangerous.
B: Yeah, I stack up plates without noticing.
A: Is the fish fresh at conveyor belt sushi?
B: Hit or miss, but it's cheap.
A: He's such a yapper.
B: Fr, I couldn't get a word in.
A: The Uber driver was a total yapper.
B: Did you give him 5 stars though?
A: Stop being a yapper and listen.
B: I'm just expressing myself!
A: No cilantro on my tacos, please.
B: It tastes like soap to you?
A: I love cilantro, pile it on.
B: You're lucky, I can't stand it.
A: This salsa has too much cilantro.
B: Perfect for me, pass it here.
A: He texted me out of the blue.
B: After ghosting you? The audacity.
A: It started raining out of the blue.
B: NYC weather is bipolar.
A: She quit her job out of the blue.
B: Must have been fed up.

primary: I'll get out of your hair.
meaning: 이제귀찮게 안 할게 / 방해 안 하고 갈게
examples: A: Thanks for the help, I'm busy now.
B: Cool, I'll get out of your hair.
A: I need to finish this report.
B: Alright, I'll get out of your hair then.
A: Stay for dinner?
B: Nah, I'll get out of your hair, you look tired.

primary: Give a big round of applause to ~
examples: A: Give a big round of applause to our guest!
B: *Clapping loudly*
A: Next up, give a big round of applause to DJ Khalid!
B: Another one!
A: Let's give a big round of applause to the chef.
B: The food was fire, he deserves it.

meaning: 할 말이 좀 있어 / 상의할 게 있어
examples: A: Can we meet? I have something to discuss.
B: Sounds serious. What's up?
A: I have something to discuss regarding the lease.
B: Ugh, they raising the rent?
A: Hey, I have something to discuss about last night.
B: Oh no, was I embarrassing?

primary: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go
examples: A: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go.
B: Agreed, I don't want weird vibes.
A: I think you took that the wrong way.
B: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go then.
A: We good?
B: Yeah, glad we cleared up any misunderstandings before we go.

primary: Put in a good word for me.
meaning: 내 얘기 좀 잘해줘 / 나 좀 잘 봐달라고 해줘
examples: A: I'm applying to your company.
B: Send me your resume.
A: Can you put in a good word for me?
B: Say less, I got you.
A: She likes you, put in a good word for me with her friend.
B: I'll try, but no promises.

meaning: 그냥 내 생각은 그래 / 내 의견은 이래
examples: A: You shouldn't text him effectively.
B: You think?
A: Yeah, he's playing games. That's my two cents.
B: I hate that you're right.
A: Sell the stock now. That's my two cents.
B: I'll think about it.
A: I have bad news. No knee jerk reaction, okay?
B: Okay, I'm listening.
A: He quit.
B: What?! ...Okay, no knee jerk reaction. We can fix this.
A: When you see the dent, no knee jerk reaction please.
B: You crashed my car?!

meaning: 그냥 하는 말이야 / 내 말은 그렇다는 거지
examples: A: That shirt is... bright.
B: You don't like it?
A: I'm just saying, it's loud.
B: Hater.
A: He's not gonna change. I'm just saying.
B: I know, but I love him.
A: You were happy five minutes ago.
B: I know, I'm very moody.
A: Don't take it personal, she's very moody.
B: Hard to keep up with her.
A: I need chocolate when I'm very moody.
B: Note taken.
A: My phone is acting up.
B: Did you try turning it off and on?
A: My knee is acting up again.
B: Getting old, huh?
A: The car is acting up.
B: Mechanic time, prepare your wallet.
A: The elevator is broken.
B: That's really inconvenient, we live on the 10th floor.
A: Cash only?
B: Yeah, that's really inconvenient.
A: They rescheduled the meeting to Friday at 6pm.
B: That's really inconvenient for my weekend plans.

meaning: 인생 즐기면서 살아 / 후회 없이 살아
examples: A: She travels every month.
B: She really lives life to the fullest.

meaning: 좀 즐기면서 살아 / 팍팍하게 살지 마
examples: A: I shouldn't eat the cake.
B: Come on, live a little!

B: Yeah, live a little, sleep when you're dead.

primary: This is not a knee-jerk reaction.

primary: Its not going through the motions

B: Always down for K-BBQ.

B: Depends on where we going.

meaning: 나도 그러고 싶은데 (못 해) / 맘은 굴뚝같은데

meaning: 이건 예상 못 했네 / 이렇게 될 줄이야

B: He's 30 acting like 13.
A: Stop whining and grow up.
B: Harsh but true.

primary: He is usually on top of responses
meaning: 걔 답장 칼이야 / 연락 잘 돼
examples: A: Why hasn't he emailed back?
B: Weird, he is usually on top of responses.
A: I love that he texts back fast.
B: Yeah, he is usually on top of responses.
A: No reply in 3 days?
B: Unlike him, he is usually on top of responses.

meaning: 속는 셈 치고 믿어주기 / 일단 믿어줌
examples: A: I think he forgot.
B: Give him the benefit of the doubt.
A: She looks suspicious.
B: Let's give her the benefit of the doubt for now.

B: Cynical much?

B: Please, I need a distraction.

B: Good idea.

B: Gym therapy.

B: I am, and he's still wrong.

B: Maybe.

meaning: 존버해 / 눈에 띄지 말고 조용히 있어
examples: A: The cops are outside.
B: Keep a low profile.

B: Respect that.

B: Easy does it.

B: It serves you right, slow down.

B: The remote?

B: A screwdriver?

B: No idea.

examples: A: My old phone bit the dust.
B: Time for an upgrade.

B: Water it!

B: Okay, start from the beginning.

meaning: 진짜 백만 년 만이다 / 너무 오랜만이야
examples: A: It's been ages since we hung out.
B: Too long.
A: How is she? It's been ages.
B: She's good, married now.

B: Still smells the same.

primary: you skipped too much, don't forget I am going to punish you if you ignore what I said
meaning: 너 너무 많이 건너뛰었어, 내 말 무시하면 혼날 줄 알아
examples: A: I skipped the intro.
B: Don't skip, pay attention.

B: Just warning you, don't ignore it.

B: Good.

B: Set position to now.

B: Start with your room.

B: On it.

B: Yeah, we're good.

meaning: 잡생각 좀 없애다 / 머리 좀 식히다
examples: A: Gaming helps take my mind off things.
B: Same.

B: Go big or go home.

meaning: 내 머리 꼭대기에 있네 / 이해가 안 돼
examples: A: Did you get the joke?
B: Nope, went over my head.

B: Too technical.

B: Okay, 5 year old version.

meaning: 내 능력 밖이야 / 무슨 말인지 모르겠어
examples: A: Can you fix the car?
B: This is way over my head.

meaning: 너무 의미 부여하지 마 / 오바해서 생각하지 마
examples: A: Why did he use a period?

meaning: 무슨 일 있어? / 왜 그렇게 꽁해 있어?
examples: A: You look sad. What's eating you?
